deliberation: The narrative of being seized by a ‘hand’ belongs to the internal reality of the vision. I focused on formulaic or evaluative expressions. deliberation: Examined כבוד אלהי ישראל and the comparison כמראה אשר ראיתי בבקעה. In Ezekiel, ‘the glory of the God of Israel’ is a technical term for the visible theophanic manifestation previously described; here it is referenced, not used figuratively. The comparison ‘like the vision I saw in the valley’ simply identifies it as the same phenomenon, without introducing a new image field. I judge the language here as internal to the visionary world and not functioning as figurative rhetoric.

Noted the command שָׂא־נָא עֵינֶיךָ as a conventional Hebrew idiom for ‘look’ rather than a literal lifting of physical eyes as an end in itself. Also, the phrase סמל הקנאה הזה repeats the metonymic epithet for the idol seen earlier.

deliberation: The verse describes movement to the courtyard entrance and the discovery of a hole in the wall. These are elements within the vision’s physical setting, not idiomatic or figurative in the rhetoric. No metaphor, simile, or other figure is evident.

The command to dig through the wall and the resulting opening are concrete visionary actions. I considered whether ‘dig through the wall’ might function metaphorically for uncovering hidden sins, but in context it is the literal means, within the vision, by which Ezekiel accesses a concealed chamber; the figurative force is carried by what he then sees, not by the verb itself.

The instruction ‘Enter and see the vile abominations that they are practicing here’ is straightforward. ‘Abominations’ (תועבות) is a value‑laden term but not itself a metaphor here; it directly names ritually/morally detestable acts. No metaphor, simile, merism, or idiom is present beyond normal literal usage.

The verse literally describes drawings of creepy things, beasts, and all the idols on the walls. Two expressions carry figurative load: (1) גִּלּוּלֵי, a pejorative term whose probable etymology (‘dung‑things’ or ‘pellets’) metaphorically degrades idols, and (2) again בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל as a metonymy for the people.

deliberation: This verse simply announces that Ezekiel will see even greater abominations. The wording is direct; ‘abominations’ is evaluative but not figurative, and no idioms or metaphors appear in the Hebrew beyond normal usage.

The verse reports women sitting and weeping for Tammuz at the gate of the house of YHWH. Their weeping is literal mourning in a cultic rite, not metaphorical. Although Tammuz worship itself is symbolic of fertility cycles, the wording here is descriptive, not figurative.

The speech formula repeats the pattern ‘Have you seen? You shall see greater abominations than these.’ The superlative sense of ‘greater’ is comparative, not hyperbolic in this context, and there are no metaphors, similes, or idioms beyond straightforward discourse.

The description of men standing between portico and altar, with their backs toward the temple and faces east, bowing to the sun, functions as a literal account of their posture and ritual direction within the vision. While their physical turning of backs implies spiritual apostasy, the Hebrew expression itself is not idiomatic; it describes actual orientation. No clear lexical metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond standard cultic terms appears.

Several figurative elements cluster here: (1) בֵּית יְהוּדָה as metonymy for the people of Judah; (2) מָלְאוּ אֶת־הָאָרֶץ חָמָס, ‘they have filled the land with violence’, as hyperbolic saturation imagery with ‘land’ metonymic for society; (3) לְהַכְעִיסֵנִי, ‘to provoke Me to anger’, an anthropopathic metaphor of God being goaded like a human; and (4) שֹׁלְחִים אֶת־הַזְּמוֹרָה אֶל־אַפָּם, an obscure but clearly figurative/idiomatic expression involving a ‘branch’ and their ‘nose’.
